awd_titl_txt: Women of Color in STEM Disciplines: Building on Success
awd_abstract_narration: In an effort to address the disproportionately low representation of women of color in the STEM disciplines, the Institute for Womens Policy Research (IWPR) will host a high-level convening of national experts on women of color with the intent of producing a report that will not only explore the challenges that women of color face in the STEM disciplines, but also put forth promising programmatic and policy changes for increasing the representation of women of color in STEM careers. The IWPR report will be disseminated widely through a broad range of networks and organizations, including relevant professional societies, foundations, academic institutions, policymakers interested in STEM, and gender related organizations.  It is envisaged that the work of IWPR will result in expedited progress in increasing the representation of women of color.  Additionally, this activity may also provide a foundation upon which alternative strategies for women from other special populations can be built.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
IWPR’s project “Women of Color in STEM Disciplines: Building on Success,” addressed the underrepresentation of STEM women faculty of color by organizing a convening bringing together nearly 50 experts to discuss barriers to progress and promising approaches to accelerate change, and writing and distributing a report with findings and recommendations from the proceedings. While a great deal of research and many programs have focused on improving women's access to STEM faculty jobs overall, few efforts have concentrated on women of color in the STEM professoriate, even though most accounts suggest that women of color face unique issues that can only be addressed through research and initiatives that explore the intersection of gender and race. Focusing on women faculty of color, the convening addressed issues that are essential to increasing the participation and success of women of color in STEM fields and advancing the nation’s global leadership in STEM, such as work-life balance in STEM academic workplaces and the impact of workplace climate issues on STEM women faculty of color. Following the event, IWPR prepared a report that summarized highlights from the convening and included original data analysis on women of color in STEM.

Held on May 10 in Washington, DC and planned with an expert advisory committee, the convening, “Accelerating Change for Women of Color Faculty in STEM: Policy, Action, and Collaboration,” featured presentations illuminating reasons that progress for women of color has been slow and pointing to places where additional information is needed to effect change. One presenter spoke about how the glass ceiling, sexual harassment, and “microaggressions and incivilities” hinder progress for women of color in academic STEM workplaces. Others addressed issues such as career-life balance and the relatively limited access of women faculty of color to mentoring and support networks. Participants emphasized the importance of interventions that stress training and accountability in hiring and promotion practices, expanded workplace flexibility, and family and medical leave policies. In addition, they identified a need for new research that addresses existing data gaps on topics such as the hiring and recruitment of women of color in STEM by discipline, rates of progress for women faculty of color in STEM by race/ethnicity and discipline, and the roles of sponsorship and mentoring in advancing the careers of women faculty of color in STEM.

At the convening, participants engaged in working group sessions in which they identified and prioritized recommendations for institutions, advocates, and funders designed to increase the representation and continued advancement of STEM women faculty of color. Recommendations include creating institutional ratings on the inclusion of women faculty of color in STEM, building a web-based information resource on STEM women faculty of color, and developing a national standard for valuing the volunteer and service work that many women faculty of color perform. Additional suggestions include providing greater transparency about the gender and racial/ethnic backgrounds of those who apply for and receive federal grants, requiring diverse search committees for new faculty hires, and encouraging institutions to implement mentoring plans that acknowledge common barriers and inequities affecting women faculty of color in STEM.

To ensure that the recommendations reach as wide an audience as possible, IWPR prepared a report that summarized the convening’s findings and presented original data on women of color in STEM. The report analyzed rates of progress in STEM degrees earned by women and men of color and white women and men over the past two decades at the bachelor’s, master’s, and doctorate levels, as well as progress for female and male STEM faculty by race/ethnicity and discipline. The analysis shows that although some progress has been made, URM women still constitute just 2.1 percent of the STEM professoriate, despite being 13 percent of the working-age U.S. population, and their representation is especially low in certain disciplines, such as computer and mathematical sciences.

IWPR has posted the report, press release, and an overview of the project to its project website (http://www.iwpr.org/publications/accelerating-change-for-women-faculty-of-color-in-stem-policy-action-and-collaboration) and distributed the report to press, legislators and staff on Capitol Hill, convening participants, relevant professional societies, and IWPR’s general interest list of more than 11,000 individuals. In addition, IWPR has worked with organizations such as the American Council on Education and Society of Women Engineers to ensure that the report reaches a wide audience. ACE included a graph from the report on its blog (“Friday Fact in Brief”), and IWPR co-hosted a Tweet Chat on women faculty of color in STEM with SWE, National Society of Black Engineers, and the office of Congresswoman Eddie Bernice Johnson that generated 578 tweets, reaching 201,436 people. IWPR has also discussed the convening and report findings with high-level academic administrators and received media attention from the influential publication, Nature. IWPR will continue to seek opportunities to inform members of the press about the report’s findings and recommendations.
